of what we're seeing,

you can apply to supply
chains more generally,
but particularly within retail and CPG,
we're seeing a lot of demand and desire

to really line up all
those different parts
of their supply chain

to give them the flexibility

And what is a really quickly

And that's consumer demands.
It's all sorts of, you know, industry

and regulations being put
on these organizations.

And so they really want that
ability to be able to flex,

to understand their end-to-end,
to make better decisions,

And sometimes their legacy supply chain

management capabilities

to many organizations,

the silos of data and
the silos of information

And so being able to

And so it's really unpicking that

You can get much more nuanced

And so as you can start to automate

it just opens their eyes
to, you know, some of the inefficiencies,

So there's lots of different
ways to approach it,

And that's a nice shift in the narrative

So if we go back to

generative AI doesn't

learning algorithms

So it's not necessarily

And so, I mean, there's all

but it's not how do we
solve a problem with GenAI?
It's what problems are we trying to solve?

And oh, actually GenAI
is a really great way
of solving this problem.

So it's a slight maturing,
I think, of the conversation

and the understanding with
our different custom sets
on what that brings to the table.
- I see, I see.

supply chain is many, many

And we often just gloss over,

So understanding the benefits of bringing

You just need the strong

And so really capture the hearts

Like I said, thinking

Engage data strategy team.
